article.title: Data_compression_ratio
article.paragraph: broaderData compressionData compression ratio, also known ascompression power, is acomputer scienceterm used to quantify the reduction in data-representation size produced by a data compression algorithm. The data compression ratio is analogous to the physicalcompression ratioused to measure physical compression of substances.
article.heading: Definitions
article.paragraph: Data compression ratio is defined as the ratio between theuncompressed sizeandcompressed size:cite newsPixel grids, bit rate and compression ratioBroadcast Engineeringhttp://broadcastengineering.com/storage-amp-networking/pixel-grids-bit-rate-and-compression-ratio2007-12-012013-06-05cite newsDigital Video and HD: Algorithms and Interfaces2nd[[Charles Poynton]][[Morgan Kaufmann Publishers]]97801239192672012-02-072013-06-05cite newsHigh Efficiency Video Coding (HEVC) text specification draft 10 (for FDIS & Consent)JCT-VChttp://phenix.it-sudparis.eu/jct/doc_end_user/current_document.php?id2013-01-172013-06-05cite newsThe H.264 Advanced Video Coding (AVC) StandardLogitechhttp://www.logitech.com/assets/45120/logitechh.pdfPDF2013-06-05cite newsWhite Paper on Performance Characteristics of MPEG-2 Long GoP vs AVC-I video compression techniques for Broadcast Applications[[Sony]]http://pro.sony.com/bbsccms/assets/files/micro/xdcam/solutions/MPEG-2_Long_GoP_vs_AVC_Comp-Strategies.pdfPDF2013-06-05

Thus a representation that compresses a 10MegaByteMBfile to 2MB has a compression ratio of 10/2 = 5, often notated as an explicit ratio, 5:1 (read "five" to "one"), or as an implicit ratio, 5/1. Note that this formulation applies equally for compression, where the uncompressed size is that of the original; and for decompression, where the uncompressed size is that of the reproduction.
Sometimes thespace savingsis given instead, which is defined as the reduction in size relative to the uncompressed size:
Thus a representation that compresses a 10MB file to 2MB would yield a space savings of 1 - 2/10 = 0.8, often notated as a percentage, 80%.
For signals of indefinite size, such asstreaming audioand video, the compression ratio is defined in terms of uncompressed and compressedBit ratedata ratesinstead of data sizes:
and instead of space savings, one speaks ofdata-rate savings, which is defined as the data-rate reduction relative to the uncompressed data rate:

For example, uncompressed songs in CD format have a data rate of 16 bits/channel x 2 channels x 44.1 kHz 1.4 Mbit/s, whereasAdvanced Audio CodingAACfiles on an iPod are typically compressed to 128 kbit/s, yielding a compression ratio of 10.9, for a data-rate savings of 0.91, or 91%.
When the uncompressed data rate is known, the compression ratio can be inferred from the compressed data rate.
article.heading: Lossless vs. lossy
article.paragraph: Lossless compressionof digitized data such as video, digitized film, and audio preserves all the information, but it does not generally achieve compression ratio much better than 2:1 because of the intrinsicinformation entropyentropyof the data. Compression algorithms which provide higher ratios either incur very large overheads or work only for specific data sequences (e.g. compressing a file with mostly zeros).S. Mittal and J. Vetter, "A Survey Of Architectural Approaches for Data Compression in Cache and Main Memory Systems", IEEE Transactions on Parallel and Distributed Systems, 2015.In contrast,lossy compression(e.g.JPEGfor images, orMP3andOpus (audio format)Opusfor audio) can achieve much higher compression ratios at the cost of a decrease in quality, such as Bluetooth audio streaming, as visual or audio compression artifacts from loss of important information are introduced. A compression ratio of at least 50:1 is needed to get1080ivideo into a 20 Mbit/sMPEG transport stream.
article.heading: Uses
article.paragraph: The data compression ratio can serve as a measure of thecomplexityof a data set or signal, in particular it is used to approximate thealgorithmic information theoryalgorithmic complexity.
